lines.content: Duke is a software application that can store, load and display a list of tasks dynamically. The following sections will explain its features and demonstrate on how to use it.
This feature simply adds a task to the record list. There are three different types of tasks as shown below:
To add a task, invoke the following commands followed by the required task descriptions as shown in the following sub-sections.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 1 task in the list.
Note: A todo task is indicated by `[T]` as shown above
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 1 task in the list.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 1 task in the list.
Note: A deadline task is indicated by `[D]` as shown above
- Date, StartTime and EndTime must be provided
- Constraint: Period of event must be within same day
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 1 task in the list.
Note: A event task is indicated by `[E]` as shown above
This feature simply prints all the tasks found in the record list. If the list is empty, an empty list message will be printed instead.
There is no task in your list.
Here are the tasks in your list:
Note: Output 2 will be used to demonstrate the find operation in the next section below
This feature simply query the record list for matching task based on the type of find command. There are two variations to the find operation as shown below:
Note: Demonstration of Find Operation is relative to Output 2 of List Operation
- Provide a keyword to be matched
Expected Output 1: No Matching Task Found
OOPS!!! No matching task is found in your list.
Here are the matching tasks in your list:
### findd - Find Task By Date (Deadline/Event Only)
Expected Output 1: No Matching Task Found
There is no deadline/event with the matching date.
This feature allows the user to change the working status of a specified task. For example, a task can be marked to indicate that it is done or unmarked when it is not done.
Note: Task is unmarked by default when first added
- Task Index is relative to the current list
- Use `list` to display all the tasks if unsure of Task Index
Nice! I've marked this task as done:
For Empty List, the program simply prints the following message:
There is no task in your list.
- Task Index is relative to the current list
- Use `list` to display all the tasks if unsure of Task Index
OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:
For Empty List, the program simply prints the following message:
There is no task in your list.
This feature simply removes a task specified by the user from the record list.
- Task Index is relative to the current list
- Use `list` to display all the tasks if unsure of Task Index
Now you have 4 tasks in the list.
For Empty List, the program simply prints the following message:
There is no task in your list.

There exist a storage that automatically updates its internal list at the instance when a task is added, marked, unmarked or deleted within the record list. The list stored in the storage will be retained even after the program closes and will automatically be loaded back into the program when it is relaunched.
Note: Storage refers to data text file
1. Click on the link to download the latest version of Duke.
2. Open command line local to duke.jar.

public abstract class DukeException extends Exception {
* Represents exception when no keyword is provided for find command.
* Represents exception when no task description is given for todo, deadline or event task when adding task.
* Represents exception when 24-hr format time is not provided for either deadline or event.
* Represents exception when date time references such as /by (for deadline) and /at (for event) are not provided.
* Represents exception when date time reference /by is not provided for deadline.
* Represents exception when date time reference /at is not provided for event.
* Represents exception when valid start time, end time or both are not provided for event.
* Represents exception when valid task index is not provided for mark, unmark or delete.
* Represents exception when an undefined command is provided.
* Deals with making sense of the user command.
* Processes the user command and prepares for corresponding command.
* @return The command type to be executed. If invalid, returns incorrect command-type.
* @exception MissingListIndexException If no task list index provided to mark, unmark or delete a task.
* @exception EmptyTaskDescriptionException If no task description provided to add any type of task.
* @exception MissingDeadlineDateTimeReferenceException If /by not provided for deadline description.
* @exception MissingEventDateTimeReferenceException If /at not provided for event description.
* @exception ParseException If date format provided for deadline/event is not valid (dd/mm/yyyy).
* @exception DateTimeParseException If date format provided for deadline/event is not valid (dd/mm/yyyy).
* @exception MissingEventTimeException If event start time, end time or both are not provided.
* @exception InvalidTimeFormatException If event start time, end time or both are not valid (24-hr format).
* @exception EmptyKeywordException If no keyword provided to find matching task description.
public Command parseCommand(String userInput) throws MissingListIndexException, EmptyTaskDescriptionException,
